title: 111_s210
content: The "Right Start Child Care and Education Act of 2009" increases the employer-provided child care credit by raising the creditable percentage of child care expenditures to 35% and resource and referral expenditures to 20%. The maximum credit is also increased to $225,000. These amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2008. The "Right Start Child Care and Education Act of 2009" increases the employer-provided child care credit by raising the creditable percentage of child care expenditures to 50% and resource and referral expenditures to 35%. The maximum credit is also increased to $12,000. Additionally, the credit is now refundable. The "Right Start Child Care and Education Act of 2009" increases the employer-provided child care credit to 50% of child care expenditures and 35% of resource and referral expenditures, with a maximum credit of $12,000. The credit is now refundable. Subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the tax code is amended to include technical changes related to refundable credits. The tax code is amended by replacing references to "section 21" with "section 36A" in various paragraphs and subsections. The tax code is amended by inserting "section 36A" in various paragraphs and subsections. Sec. 36A allows for expenses related to household and dependent care services necessary for gainful employment. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2008. Additionally, a 3-year credit is introduced for individuals with child care-related degrees working in licensed child care facilities. The Right Start Child Care and Education Credit is introduced under SEC. 25E. It provides a 3-year credit for individuals with child care-related degrees working in licensed child care facilities. The Right Start Child Care and Education Credit offers a $2,000 credit for eligible child care providers for the taxable year, with a 3-year limit on claiming the credit. An individual must elect to apply this section each year and cannot make the election if it has been in effect for the past 3 years. The Right Start Child Care and Education Credit provides a $2,000 credit for eligible individuals with a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or related field who perform 1,200 hours of child care services at a qualified facility. The Right Start Child Care and Education Credit offers a $2,000 credit for eligible individuals with a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or related field who provide 1,200 hours of child care services at a qualified facility that meets state or local regulations. The Right Start Child Care and Education Credit provides a $2,000 credit for eligible individuals with a bachelor's degree in early childhood education who offer child care services at a qualified facility. The amendment increases the exclusion for employer-provided dependent care assistance to $7,500 ($3,750) and applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2008.
